msDesc.head:
Letter from
Frances M. Edgeworth
to Claudine Béatrix Terray de Belbauf, , May 5. 24

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

revisionDesc.change: Created file for letter, encoded letter

div.p:
It is so very long since I have heard
any thing of you my dear Beatrix
that I almost fear in writing to you
lest you should have quite forgotten
me - and should think me very im
pertinent impertinent in addressing you as I
would have done three years ago -
and yet I cannot believe that
Mme
Madame
la Comtesse de Belbauf can be so
very different from the dear Beatrix
that I loved as to be offended at
what is certainly meant as kindess
- I had hoped that you would have
persuaded
M Monsieur . de Belbauf to have
brought you to England - and that I
should have had the pleasure of seeing
you again - This I fear is a vain

hope - some how you French ladies
do not find it so easy or so agreeable
to travel as we Englishwomen do
- But still I had flattered myself you
would have written either to me or
to Harriet - good kind
Mme Madame
de Vinde
has not been at all good or kind to
us of late - as she had quite left off
writing to my sister - But I now
hope to hear of you at least from
the friend who takes this letter a
Mr. Strickland - And if you are still
the same goodnatured good-natured
Beatrix I
knew I still have a little hope
that you will write to me - and tell
me something about yourself - Are
either of your pretty sisters married
- Your brother I suppose is now in
the army and quite at his own dis
=posal disposal . Have you any children
in short I wish to know of all that

interests and occupies you.
One of my sisters whom you do not
know has just been married very
much to her satisfcation & that of
all her family - Her husband is in
the army - as soon as ever he can
get leave of absence they intend
going to the Continent for some
months - Should they go to Paris
I should hope that you would be kind
to my sister - but I do not know
when that may be.

I often look back & so does Harriet
to the pleasant days we spent with
you at La Celle and above all that
one that we spent as Malmaison - I
should so like to return to Paris &
see all my friends there again for
I still must think that those who
were so kind to me & of whom I was
so fond, must be my friends - When
I am married I shall certainly as my
husband to take me to Paris - At present

I have no hopes of going - My sister Marian
has been very unwell for the last
year and her health is still so un
certain that she is not equal to a long
journey - You may believe that it is
very melancholy to all of us to see so
good and kind a friend suffer - but
now that summer is coming I hope
she will grow stronger

I am afraid that you have
never received a book that
Har
riet Harriet
and I sent you a long time ago
according to the promsie we made you
which I fear you must have thought
we had forgotten.

Pray remember me most affection
ately affectionately to
Mr. Monsieur
& Madame de Vinde - &
to your sisters - Again let me beg
you to write to me - Harriet &
Maria join me in kind wishes to
you and yours
div.closer:
Believe me dear Beatrix
your sincerely affectionate
Frances M Edgeworth
